job_title: Senior Communications Specialist in Chicago, IL

cons: Nothing to report as of now

review_title: Compensation inadequate and upper management is antiquated
job_title: Healthcare Data Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: I loved my direct coworkers
cons: Upper management is slow-moving and does not react to employee feedback. They host calls and surveys to collect input, but change never happened. Despite a “great” year, the only bonuses to non-management employees were in the form of gift cards.

pros: Nice people good benefits. And good environment
cons: Limited Career development opportunities and limited raises

pros: Strong grounding in association work. Very talented and capable coworkers.
cons: Sometimes it felt like the organization's main goal was to protect the salaries of hospital CEOs as opposed to supporting the health and healthcare of Americans.

pros: Coworkers, benefits of larger company, great healthcare plan
cons: Low pay, your work environment/workload depends on who you work for - my situation was negative but others I knew had much better workloads.

pros: Terrific benefits, sense of mission, opportunities for advancement.
cons: Not extremely innovative, many people have been in their jobs for decades.

review_title: Good experience, but lacks a Sales Leader
pros: Solid benefits and all federal holidays are already built in as time off.
cons: Every year the commission structure would change. Required Hybrid model (3 days in office), but sales team would be more effective being remote and traveling to clients as needed.

pros: Great mission. Really smart people. Telework environment.
cons: IT is behind. Can be hard to find a niche.

pros: Good benefits and nice people

job_title: Sustainability Program Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: The people, environment, culture are the greatest
cons: Nothing, AHA provides support for everything

pros: Good benefits and decent PTO.
cons: Pay is low but there are options for getting raises each year

pros: Excellent health insurance, great office location, and coworkers made the job bearable.
cons:
Extremely low pay, siloed departments, lack of transparency, and poor leadership. They recently got rid of tuition reimbursement as a cost savings measure. 

Executive leadership (Christina Fisher) denied that the company made layoffs in 2020/during COVID when in fact they let several people go. It was disappointing to listen to phone calls where leadership would deny layoffs when it occurred very suddenly in my department. They let people go the day before a new month began meaning those individuals were left without health care for the following month during a pandemic. It was extremely evil. The company also encouraged/gave departments the option to force people to come to the office (when all work could be successfully completed remotely) when COVID cases were extremely high. 

The organization continues to "merge" departments. Each individual "association" within the AHA used to have their own meeting planner and marketing specialist/manager but there are now meeting planning and marketing focused departments. It made collaboration very difficult and the process was handled very poorly.

Many people in positions of leadership/power that don't know how to manage.

pros:
Schedule allows for good work life balance
Great middle level management
Good benefits and time off
cons: Hybrid schedule with 3 days in office even after employees proved they could work remotely

review_title: A company with a terrific Benefits package
pros:
Benefits
Great Co-workers
Employee activities throughout the year
Good Managers
Often hiring up within company (depending on skillset, and department)

scope creep happens often
raises are minimal
Not too many places to move up administratively

job_title: Member Engagement Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Medical benefits are the best part. Their wellness rewards program has gotten a lot better over the years and you receive money for completing challenges.
cons: Bonuses were removed for most but executives a couple years ago and were expected to do more than previous years for the same pay. Emphasis on revenue all the time. Work/life balance is hard. HR recruitment doesn't recruit from inside first.

pros:
Great mission - improving health care in the U.S.
Supportive environment, fantastic people, good work.
cons: Too much work. Becoming overwhelmed.

pros: Great base pay and benefits with annual raises based on performance reviews.
cons: It was largely a popularity contest for who moved up. Lots of people seemingly doing nothing all day while others shouldered the load.

pros: Benefits, office space, people, wellness package

Lack advacement opportunties. Huge game between levels of staff. You cant learn and grow
From

pros:
Benefits, diversity, salary, vacation, ease of access to upper management, hours, employee appreciation. They include all walks of life. 
AHA went above and beyond for us during covid.
cons: Sometimes promotions can be hard to get but there isn't much that can be done to alleviate this. It's the age old "someone must leave" to move up. But salary increases and benefits usually offset this.

pros: Good place, like it a lot

review_title: Be careful if you have health issues
job_title: Data and Technology in Chicago, IL
pros: Good Loop location, excellent salaries at VP+ level, good work life balance at most levels
cons: Only talks the diversity talk, doesn't staff or fund, has a pattern of letting go employees with health issues,

pros: People there are really great
cons: The pay is just terrible

pros:
Benefits are top notch & salary is ok
Individuals below executive management are a great group to work with/for
cons:
The current executive management team has taken a 100+ year old company and nearly driven in it into the ground over the last five years.  Employee moral is the lowest I have seen it in my 15+ years with this company & while HR is fully aware of this, have no intention of trying to "fix" the problem.   HR serves only at the pleasure of Rick Pollack and his direct reports.  The "WE CARE" program of AHA values is a complete sham and there is absolutely no respect for the worker bees that keep the company running.

I think employees in general are on board with AHA's mission & vision, but AHA is a dinosaur that  is slowly going towards extinction and does not have the proper individuals at the top to strategically turn the organization around.  AHA is a membership organization and the top brass have no inclination in serving or interacting with the members and membership is starting to recognize this lack of respect and interest.

review_title: Overall, a good place with some room for improvement
pros: Location, and job opportunities within the organization. It's a good place to build one's career. It is also a good place to network and get to know other people in the health care field.
cons: Their opportunities for advancement seem to be quite limited particularly if you come in at a relatively senior level, or a researcher level.  The people who grow come in at clerical levels, and stay for 40 years. They encourage this and recognize it a lot. But in this day and age, being somewhere for 40 years is not necessarily a good thing. AHA needs a better strategy to groom people with several advanced degrees who come in at senior levels.

pros: Nice place to park yourself if you have a second career/job/education goal to attend to. Normal 38-hour workweek, low performance expectations, and non-existing reward system encourage you to apply your drive/passion to something outside work.
cons:
Endless politics and the bureaucracy suck the life out of most people working there. As a result, employees give up and follow the "success" track of not making waves with anyone and repeating tactics/strategies that were done the prior year, regardless if they make sense or not. Hard work/good work is secondary to finding and keeping a "connected" manager who will protect you.

Different internal groups compete with each other for revenue. This creates major conflicts between groups and confuses the small pool of clients who are the source of those revenues.

pros: The American Hospital Association is an association. Folks that work here are focused on making a difference for members, patients and their families. Benefits are wonderful and HR tries to keep folks around as long as possible. Many people have been around for 15 years or more.
cons: As this is an Association, the organizational hierarchy is very flat and a majority of the workforce is older. There aren't very many paths for career advancement. As a milennial, I felt as though I was working with folks who were old enough to be my parents and grandparents. It was hard to be taken seriously.

pros: Great benefits, connection to thought leaders, internally motivated, intelligent, and caring coworkers.
cons: Leadership within AHA fears the future and seeks to be "innovative" without giving mid-level management the opportunity to implement strategy before the next shiny "disruption" changes executive focus. My division was terrifically understaffed. Burnout was rampant, as was turnover. Direction changed frequently without time to implement. Leadership told staff they "didn't have the skills we need to be successful," but didn't allow time for professional development, which lead to disengagement in an overworked and underappreciated team.  Leadership would call out individual staff members in large groups for poor performance, but did not publicly recognize improvement or success. For an organization with a focus on quality improvement and patient safety, internally a culture of continuous improvement was severely lacking and needed.

review_title: Leadership team is the biggest joke
pros: Great benefits and location
cons: This used to be a great place to work until Rick Pollack took over and assembled his horrible leadership team. It’s gone from an organization with happy employees, great morale where everyone now is miserable and looking for another job. They have these fake all employee meetings where they try to tell employees how great everything g is and that we have these great new values which are such a joke. The AHA tries to present this great image of what they want people to believe they are. It’s a really sad day at this association. They also moved someone who worked in one of the PMG’s to be the Chief People Officer. Listening to her at that meeting was painful. It’s pretty clear to everyone she has no clue  what she’s doing. Time to go and find real talent to lead the HR function. The AHA should get their act together if they want to try and save this place.

review_title: Trying to move into the future but somewhat stuck in the past
pros: There are some great, hard-working, passionate people working here. Many in the organization are committed to help fulfill the AHA's mission.
cons: Unfortunately, there are pockets of "lifers" who do nothing but sit in their offices, disengage, produce nothing, and severely impact of the morale of those around them. HR turns a blind eye to this,  In addition, and perhaps in part because of this,   there are not many opportunities to move up, although executive management is extremely top heavy.

pros: Wonderful Mission. Most of the work teams were extremely collaborative within themselves. good perks and benefits. some of the managers are pretty awesome.
cons: No consistency in how workers are treated; worker bees who get the work done are often ignored, unfairly compensated, and even let go. Managers and executives who count on those worker bees to make them look good are often overpaid, out-of-the-loop, and revered. The DC employees can do no wrong. Executives are not honest in their communication - they talk down to employees and include a lot of "fluff" but no detail. stop treating employees like children.

review_title: Overall, I enjoyed my experience at the AHA because I was able to impact the employee population.
pros: The AHA provides  a strong sense of commitment to their mission, vision and values.  The organization offers an outstanding benefits package with a focus on employee needs.
cons: Some of the challenges are working with management with inflated egos, which result in a large number of terminations  with severance packages.

pros:
The majority of AHA staff are good to work with - professional and knowledgable.  Even "lifers" (staff who've been there for years and years) are in the game, which is refreshing and pretty unusual in my pretty extensive experience.

Pay and benefits are excellent among membership associations in Chicago.  

SOME sections within AHA have good employee autonomy.  That is, if you demonstrate common sense and knowledge about your area of responsibility, you can make decisions and have management's support.  

Members are great - responsibe, responsive, knowledgable and, largely, good-humored.
cons:
Some sections, and even entire departments, work in vaccuums.  It can be grueling to figure out what other areas are working on, which makes it frequently impossible to avoid recreating the wheel. realize scales of economy, avoid mistakes, etc.  That stinks. So, lack of communication is a problem and frustration if you're really into performing excellently on AHA's behalf.

There's also inequiity in staff management.  A few workers are completely unaccountable when their behavior/productivity/attendance is abysmal.   Yeah, it happens everywhere, but this is blatant stuff that even staff who have no contact with these people know what's going on.  The few offenders run roughshod over members, coworkers, and even managers.  And yet, HR does...what?  What's this about in an organization of this size?  A few bad apples can really stink it up for a lot of coworkers.

And, there's more than a few mavericks among middle managers.  The "do know and ask for forgiveness later" types.  They just don't get that their actions and decisions effect a whole lot of people, so if you maverick-types would knock it off, that would be great.

pros: Great benefits, decent salaries, nice people, overall.
cons: Bad management. Top level executives talk a good game, but when it comes down to department managers and association top management, a lot of hypocrisy. Many people unhappy with their department management, but stay a long time because of the great benefits.

review_title: The AHA provides a great example of why associations are a dying business model.
pros: Benefits are the only benefit unless you like being bullied by your boss and working with processes and systems from 1985.
cons: I worked for one of those groups (AHRMM) and the following describe what you will most likely encounter from working there:  1) you will learn how to deal with a boss who is a passive aggressive bully and you will be expected to just deal with it on your own. During my time (under 5 years) my boss was reported to the anonymous hotline two times within a year and received less than favorable employee evaluation scores yet nothing was done to correct her behavior. When the AHA allows employees to be treated like scum it is hard to think that they truly care about the wellbeing of others. 2) the AHA provide minimal benefits to their members. I was told multiple times not focus so much time on improving the “quality” of our products even though the products had no strategy or design and looked like they came from 1987. 3) The AHA is perfect for employees who have no voice, motivation, or strategy for improvements. 4.) The AHA likes to waste money to have high dollar consultants come in and train their employees (performance excellence) yet they do not hold leaders responsible for any type of excellence so no improvements are made. 5) The AHA IT department is like none I’ve ever seen but that may be because I didn’t work in 1985 when half of their systems were developed. 6) The AHA has no business continuity. If someone is out on vacation, you just have to wait. 7) The AHA trains about process and project management because they do not believe in hiring project managers. Be ready to do two jobs when new projects come around. 8) The AHA hires skilled employees; however, they do not utilize even a quarter of their potential. Be prepared to do a lot of admin work because they do not believe in process improvements. 9) This is the perfect job for people who do not want to be held accountable for anything.

review_title: Don't join if you're young and are looking for a career
pros: Easy going attitude, no micromanaging, mostly respectful people and workplace
cons:
1. No growth opportunities, very low salary range except for people in managerial positions, Not for the employee, disparity is working privileges
2. Every concern gets pushed aside and doesn't get addressed. 
3. Spends/wastes a lot of money on frivolous engagements with external consultants but will not employees well.

review_title: old boys club,if you are non white stay away
job_title: Senior IT Professional in Chicago, IL
pros: location,some nice coworkers and easy commute
cons:
low salary,bad management mostly old boy club,if you don't belong to this circle you are out of luck.
I worked for Integration Department as IT professional,I didn't like it and I was treated differently just because I'm not white.
I was asked by management  a lot of questions about my religion and about my home country in bad way which something you will get sued for one day .
I couldn't take it no more so I lift and got much better job with more profisional company

pros:
Benefits are very good. 
Allows you to stay very current in healthcare trends
cons:
Need to be a man.  Poor management.  Poor treatment of employees. 
Many long time employees now being replaced with many new.  No systems in place for check and balance of management.  Big egos

review_title: Great Organization with Lots of Dysfunction
pros: Beautiful office in a new building; great benefits; some of the directors and managers and most of the worker bees are AWESOME!  Benefits are quite good, as is work-life balance. The people comprising the Board of Directors and Office of the Secretary are an amazing group of professionals with their hearts and minds in the right place.
cons: Compensation is weak for those who do the bulk of the work.  A highly hierarchical organization.  Executives don't look at who is running the shop for fear of having to deal with it and (horrors) possibly making some changes.  Some of the VPs and managers are insecure bullies who create busy work regularly and thrive on chaos--actually create chaos if necessary (and then hilariously complain about it!).  HR does not respond to complaints under any circumstances--any complaints or offenses (regardless of how egregious) are treated with a pat on the shoulder and a nod of "I understand".  Nothing ever changes and I suspect nothing ever will.  They have recently embraced "corporate speak" (think the late 90's); if you have a flair for it, you'll go far.  Many of the Directors and Managers (Chicago and Washington) are highly competitive and insecure, and will do their best to undermine anyone they feel is a threat--including gossip and lie. I am THRILLED that I left--my Sundays are no longer filled with dread.

job_title: Governance Operations Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits and middle management on down are good people who want to do their jobs.
cons: Upper Management very entrenched and do not treat their staff well, with some exceptions. Everyone feels overworked and management seems to block efforts towards collaboration and improvement

review_title: You won’t find another workplace that makes you feel less valued and more disrespected
pros:
-The location of the Downtown DC office is centrally located
-Colleagues can help you make it through the days
cons:
-Virtually no opportunities for advancement
-Massive pay inequities
-Promotions are rare and raises are basically nonexistent
-No real bonuses, except for VPs and above who get massive bonuses 
-A culture that totally devalues any employees who are lower than Senior Director
-Culture where lower-level employees are told they can’t talk to people in higher positions
-Forming friendships with colleagues feels frowned upon
-Leadership team are a group of older, out-of-touch employees who have been with the company for 20+ years and fuel a toxic environment
-Super outdated workplace! Working from home is discouraged or blatantly not allowed, vacation policy is old-fashioned with no ability to roll over any days. Employees are often judged for using any vacation days, while managers take off a fair amount
-Work hours aren’t very inflexible. You’re expected to be there from 8:30 am - 5:30 pm. Managers, however, have much more flexible hours and gotten leave before 4 pm 
-Lower-level employees shoulder all the blame for any mishaps 
-Conversely, managers take credit for the ideas and work of their employees and then accept bonuses for that good work without giving anything to their employees
-HR actively ignores employee complaints or genuine workplace problems 
-Managers do not help their employees grow or advance. There’s such a competitive spirit within the organization, and many managers see their employees as competition and won’t help them advance 
-No professional development opportunities 
-So many employees talk with each other about going home crying at the end of every work day because you are so beaten down and unvalued

review_title: Has changed for the bad since new CEO
pros: Great people, caring managers, ' book smart' people, talented people.
cons: CEO and direct leadership reporting to him - not people focused. Only interested is "yes" people. Bad decisions to cut staff and are paying the price now.

review_title: Don't work for Financial Services Group or whatever they call themselves now.

cons: Pay is bad.  They bait and swtich from the interview to you start your job.  Hired for marketing communications role - job was sales making 30 telemarketing cold calls/day - yuck! Fiefdoms in different sub-organizations.  They really decive employees, vendors and members.  Lifer employees think they can never get fired - AND THEY DON'T NO MATTER WHAT THEY DO!
